methods: Store used batteries in a labeled, non-metallic container.
Take to an authorized e-waste collection center or retailer with a take-back program.
Avoid storing multiple batteries together to prevent short-circuiting.
Battery.disposal: Never dispose of batteries in regular bins. Locate an e-waste facility nearby and hand over in-person.
Battery.environmental_impact: Improper disposal can leak heavy metals like lead and cadmium into the environment, polluting soil and water.

methods: Flatten boxes to save space.
Ensure cardboard is clean and dry before recycling.
Avoid recycling greasy or food-stained cardboard (e.g., pizza boxes).
Cardboard.disposal: Place in a paper/cardboard recycling bin or drop off at a municipal dry waste collection center.
Cardboard.environmental_impact: Recycling cardboard reduces deforestation and conserves energy.

methods: Rinse thoroughly to remove residues.
Do not mix broken glass with recyclable glass—dispose of it separately in a labeled container.
Avoid mixing with ceramics or light bulbs.
Glass.disposal: Use dedicated glass bins in public spaces or household recycling if available.
Glass.environmental_impact: Recycling glass reduces raw material usage and saves up to 30% energy in glass production.

methods: Disconnect cables or batteries before disposal.
Donate if still functional.
Drop at an authorized e-waste collection center.
Keyboard.disposal: Never dispose in regular trash. Use certified recyclers or e-waste bins.
Keyboard.environmental_impact: Plastic casing and internal circuitry can leach toxic chemicals over time.

methods: Remove plastic or rubber parts (if any).
Clean off food residue or oils.
Sort metals if required by local recycler (e.g., aluminum vs steel).
Metal.disposal: Take to a scrap dealer or use household metal recycling services.
Metal.environmental_impact: Reduces mining needs and air/water pollution from metal processing.

methods: Unplug and remove any detachable parts.
Check with manufacturer for take-back schemes.
Drop off at e-waste collection points.
Microwave.disposal: Do not dispose of in standard waste. Must be processed by an e-waste recycler.
Microwave.environmental_impact: Contains capacitors and heavy metals that can cause environmental harm if incinerated or dumped.

methods: Back up data and perform a factory reset.
Remove SIM and memory cards.
Drop at retailer or authorized collection center with buyback or recycling options.
Mobile.disposal: Never throw in dustbins. Hand over to authorized mobile phone recyclers.
Mobile.environmental_impact: Smartphones contain rare earth metals, plastics, and chemicals that can harm ecosystems.

methods: Remove batteries if wireless.
Ensure it's non-functional before disposal.
Drop off at e-waste drop zones or certified recyclers.
Mouse.disposal: Like all peripherals, must be handed over for e-waste treatment.
Mouse.environmental_impact: Plastic and circuits can leach microplastics and toxins.

methods: Minimize usage and opt for reusable alternatives.
Place securely in black bags to prevent contamination.
Do not mix with dry or recyclable waste.
Non Recyclable.disposal: Dispose through municipal waste collection. Ensure it goes to a sanitary landfill, not open dumping.
Non Recyclable.environmental_impact: Takes hundreds of years to decompose and often ends up in oceans or rivers.

methods: Keep clean and dry.
Do not recycle shredded paper with other sheets.
Separate glossy/magazine paper if required.
Paper.disposal: Use a dry waste bin or submit to local paper recycling units.
Paper.environmental_impact: Saves trees and reduces methane emissions from landfills.

methods: Do not attempt to dismantle PCBs manually.
Store in a cool, dry place until pickup.
Give to certified e-waste dismantlers.
PCB.disposal: Highly toxic—must be recycled in specialized facilities that extract gold, copper, and silver safely.
PCB.environmental_impact: Improper disposal can release brominated flame retardants and heavy metals.

methods: Rinse and dry to avoid contamination.
Follow local plastic code numbers (e.g., PET, HDPE).
Avoid mixing biodegradable plastics with regular plastic waste.
Plastic.disposal: Use municipal or NGO-led plastic recycling bins. Some supermarkets accept plastic return.
Plastic.environmental_impact: Plastic pollution harms marine life and creates microplastic contamination.

methods: Remove cartridges and recycle separately.
Check for buyback or trade-in programs from manufacturers.
Take to an e-waste center or tech store that accepts used hardware.
Printer.disposal: Ink residues and components require special disposal. Never throw in general waste.
Printer.environmental_impact: Ink can leak into the soil, and plastic shells increase landfill volume.

methods: Check warranty or return policies if under service.
Do not smash or dismantle (especially CRTs).
Use bulk pickup or drop off at e-waste center.
Television.disposal: CRT and LED TVs are hazardous—dispose of through formal e-waste channels.
Television.environmental_impact: Lead from screens and mercury from backlights are dangerous if released into the environment.

methods: Drain water and detach hoses before disposal.
Contact a scrap dealer or manufacturer with recycling program.
Some cities offer bulk pickup for large appliances.
Washing Machine.disposal: Needs to be processed at a large appliance recycling facility.
Washing Machine.environmental_impact: Heavy metals and plastic parts can cause soil and water pollution if not treated.
